comment_text: See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentinel_Building_(Centralia,_Illinois) "The Sentinel Building is a historic building located at 232 East Broadway in Centralia, Illinois. The building was constructed in 1881 to serve as the headquarters and printing press of the Centralia Sentinel, Centralia's daily newspaper. Renovations in 1922 and 1929 converted the building's design to the Egyptian Revival style; the change reflected the Sentinel's slogan, "Egypt's Greatest Daily", which was chosen since the newspaper served the Little Egypt region." 232 East Broadway, Centralia, Illinois. 2024 Streetview

title: Space alien figures (and those who examine them) get their own room inside Fox Cave in Ruidoso, New Mexico (LOC)
description: Highsmith, Carol M.,, 1946-, photographer. Space alien figures (and those who examine them) get their own room inside Fox Cave in Ruidoso, New Mexico 2018-03-10. 1 photograph : digital, tiff file, color. Notes: Title, date, keywords, and additional description details based on information provided by the photographer. The very real, and deep, cave had long been a cooling refuge for residents and visitors high above the often baking-hot southeast New Mexico desert. It became a quirky roadside tourist attraction in the 1950s and its thematic rooms and outdoor displays have been a fun escape from reality, too. Thanks to a supposed UFO landing in nearby Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947, aliens are a hot attraction in the region. Purchase; Carol M. Highsmith Photography, Inc.; 2020; (DLC/PP-2020:133). Forms part of Carol M. Highsmith's America Project in the Carol M. Highsmith Archive. Subjects: America--Fox Cave--Roadside Attractions--Space aliens United States--New Mexico--Lincoln County--Ruidoso. Format: Digital photographs--Color--2010-2020. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print Part Of: Highsmith, Carol M., 1946- Carol M. Highsmith Archive. (DLC) 00650024 Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/highsm.65826 Call Number: LC-DIG-highsm- 65826
comment_text: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Cave "Fox Cave is located on East Highway 70 between Roswell and Alamogordo, near Ruidoso, New Mexico. It was once used as a hideout by William H. Bonney, better known as Billy the Kid and also known as Henry Antrim, a 19th-century American gunman who participated in the Lincoln County War and became a frontier outlaw in the American Old West. Originally known as "Ice Cave" in the late 1800s and early 1900s, the rocks of Fox Cave are primarily micritic limestone. The cave was formed over thousands of years by erosion of the rock caused by the Ruidoso River." See also www.visitruidoso.com/fox-cave/ and 2024 Streetview of the outside of the cave

title: Many U.S. cities have enormous billboards, large animal sculptures, or other landmarks on the edges of key highways that runs through town (LOC)
description: Highsmith, Carol M.,, 1946-, photographer. Many U.S. cities have enormous billboards, large animal sculptures, or other landmarks on the edges of key highways that runs through town 2020-12-02. 1 photograph : digital, tiff file, color. Notes: Title, date, keywords, and additional description details based on information provided by the photographer. In Stillwater, Oklahoma, it's something quite different (some would say imposing) as it's a 22-foot-tall Transformer figure (this is one of two), outside the G&M Body Shop. He's named Optimus Prime, the other, Bumblebee. Each scrap-metal figure mimics the look of a giant "autobot" from the science-fiction "Transformers" movies. Purchase; Carol M. Highsmith Photography, Inc.; 2020; (DLC/PP-2020:133). Forms part of Carol M. Highsmith's America Project in the Carol M. Highsmith Archive. Subjects: America--Transformer giants--Optimus Prime United States--Oklahoma--Payne County--Stillwater. Format: Digital photographs--Color--2020. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print Part Of: Highsmith, Carol M., 1946- Carol M. Highsmith Archive. comment_text: Palisade Gardens Roller Skating Rink, 2838 University Ave., San Diego, California www.google.com/maps/@32.7484069,-117.1331102,3a,75.4y,0.3... • Owner: Leonard, Robert and Mortimer Zlotoff (1946-1985) • Operator/Manager: John Albert Wright (1946-1985) • Pro/Coach: Margaret S. Edwards, Henry F. Elliot Jr. • Organist: [?] • DJ: George, Leslie • Floor size: [?] • Floor type: Wood, Clear coated. • Primary reason for closing: "the cost to insure the business became larger than the income." • Opened: 1946 - 1985 • The rink closed with an event called "The Last Great Skate," which Leonard Zlotoff described as "a peaceful end." • In a 1985 interview, Wright said he was "making a buck up to the last day," but he didn't mind having Saturday nights off in his retirement. • The building was torn down in the late 1980s for the Palisades Pointe apartments. From forgottenrollerrinksofthepast.com/

"Since 1999 the formerly empty fourth plinth on Trafalgar Square has become London's most prominent showcase for temporary new sculpture." See also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourth_plinth

comment_text: Looks to have changed to be known as the YMCA Building by 2014. 612 6th Street, Las Vegas NM 87701 2014 Streetview See historical marker info at www.hmdb.org/m.asp?m=45891 'Built by M.M. Sundt Architects: Issac H. & William M. Rapp The YMCA was organized in Las Vegas in 1900 with Attorney A.T. Rogers as president. The "Y" flourished for two decades before closing in 1924. The building then served as the Las Vegas Hospital until 1952. The building is a fine example of the World's Fair Classic Style.'

comment_text: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crossroads_of_the_World "Crossroads of the World is an open-air mall on Sunset Boulevard and Las Palmas in Los Angeles. The mall features a central building designed to resemble an ocean liner surrounded by a small village of cottage-style bungalows. It was designed by Robert V. Derrah, built in 1936, and has been called America's first outdoor shopping mall." At least some of the boat-like structure still exists. 2022 Streetview

comment_text: Still there in 2019. 2019 Streetview No Streetview of Raton since then. See also www.facebook.com/cityofdustnm/photos/a.251923124956264/21... "In Raton, New Mexico, you'll find the Marchiondo Building, which was built in 1882. It's at 120-124 First Street and, as the signage indicates, was also known as The Golden Rule and New York Stores. Here you could buy anything from shirts and shoes to meat and flour. In 1913, a one-story addition was constructed at the back of the building."

comment_text: The Foster's Daily Democrat (as in gilded sign above the arched window) is still in business ( www.fosters.com/ ) in the Gannett family of papers. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foster's_Daily_Democrat One of the pictures in a grid at upper right of en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portsmouth,_New_Hampshire shows this building in 2009 and identifies the location as Market Square. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portsmouth,_New_Hampshire#/media/Fi... 2008 Streetview shows the gilded Foster's Daily Democrat sign, but by 2011 Streetview the building is occupied by an Irish gift shop.

comment_text: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniroyal_Giant_Tire "The Uniroyal Giant Tire was created by the United States Rubber Company for the 1964 New York World's Fair, where it functioned as a Ferris wheel. Since 1966 it has served as a static display in Allen Park, Michigan, alongside Interstate 94, between the Southfield Freeway interchange and Outer Drive overpass." See April 2023 Streetview

comment_text: See www.theroute-66.com/canute.html#holy-family "On the next corner, NW one, at N 2080Rd (9th St.) and Route 66. This red-brick building faces east, and has a plaque above its entrance that reads "Canute Heritage Center 1994". It was established in 1926 with Father P.P. Schaeffer as its first pastor. It closed in 1970 and now is private property. Renamed in 1994 as the "Heritage Center"." route66times.com/l/ok/canute-heritage-center.htm "In 1994 the Heritage Center purchased, renovated and moved into the 1926 Holy Family Catholic church building. You can't miss this building entering town from the east, it's on the corner of 9th and Old Highway 66." March 2021 Streetview

comment_text: On 5th Street, Columbus, MS 2018 Streetview Item 23 from www.columbusmainstreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Wal... "This bank building was designed and built in 1903 by John Stinson, owner/operator of Columbus Marble Works, and is noted for its significant architecture. In 1932, Machine Gun Kelley robbed a bank in Tupelo. Out of fear of a robbery in Columbus, Capt Sam Kaye was asked to loan a German machine gun he had brought home after WWI to the bank. It was placed on the bank’s mezzanine pointing down aimed at the front entrance. The bank hired WWI veteran, John Perry, to stand guard with the gun. Later the gun was returned to Kaye but Perry remained as a bank guard armed with a shotgun. The structure continued to serve as the main office until 1972 when growth of banking operations forced its relocation to a larger facility. In 1981, as a gesture of community goodwill and to honor an exceptional employee, the Merchants and Farmers Bank gave the building to the City of Columbus through the Columbus Civic Arts Council to be used as a Visual Arts Museum. When the Museum was relocated to Mississippi University for Women, the City returned the ownership."

comment_text: 1099 Westwood Blvd, Los Angeles, CA 90024 It has lost the unusual Bank of America sign. 2021 Streetview In 2023 it is the Broxton Brewery & Public House. According to waterandpower.org/museum/Early_Views_of_Westwood.html the building was known as the Janss Dome, completed in 1930 to house the headquarters of the Janss Investment Company, which built Westwood Village. In 1988, the Janss Investment Company Building (Janss Dome) was dedicated as a Los Angeles Historic-Cultural Monument No. 364. It is also listed in the U.S. National Register of Historic Places. 1940 and 1949 (and later) photographs in the page of Early Views of Westwood linked above show the Bank of America sign on the building.

comment_text: See a 1990s photo at digital.grinnell.edu/islandora/object/grinnell:13220 "Brenton National Bank on the northwest corner of Broad Street and Fourth Avenue in Grinnell, Iowa. The bank was formerly Merchants' National Bank designed by Louis Sullivan." 833 4th Ave 2019 Streetview www.grinnellchamber.org/en/things_to_do/history__architec... "... the centerpiece of Grinnell's architectural heritage is the Merchants National Bank, which was designed by the legendary architect Louis Sullivan. Built in 1914, it is one of Sullivan's eight Midwestern "jewel box" banks. Designated a National Historic Landmark by the US Department of the Interior, the bank currently houses the Grinnell Area Chamber of Commerce."

comment_text: www.ebay.com/itm/374109053774 shows a 1920s postcard of this school. A Jan. 18, 2008 article from the New York Times with title online "A Mining Town With a Bleak Past Starts to Blossom" [ www.nytimes.com/2008/01/18/travel/escapes/18havens.html ] mentions that "The three-story red brick Lincoln School is being converted into 17 lofts with 14-foot-high ceilings. They range in price from $299,000 to $499,000, and are meant to attract young urban couples." See www.zillow.com/homedetails/514-McKinley-Ave-Kellogg-ID-83... It looks as though the conversion has been slow. 2021 Streetview doesn't look too appealing. But a 2011 Streetview looks as though there may be some occupancy.

comment_text: east.madison.k12.wi.us/ 2222 E. Washington Av. Madison, WI 53704 2021 Streetview www.wisconsinhistory.org/Records/Property/HI102453 "While the entire Madison East High School was designed at one time, its historic-period design was built in sections between 1922 and 1939. Designed by Frank Riley, the main block was completed in 1922 with other blocks being constructed in 1925, 1932, and 1938-9. The school was planned not only to relieve the overcrowding in the city's only other public high school, but also to present a quality educational and community facility to Madison's rapidly growing east side." I think "Edison" in the caption is probably an error.

comment_text: The building is in this 2022 Streetview It is a Federal Building at 200 E Broadway according to www.loopnet.com/Listing/200-E-Broadway-St-Missoula-MT/119... It appears to be a Post Office with space above available to lease for offices. Building Type: Office Year Built: 1913 Building Height: 4 Stories Looking at Google Maps with the satellite layer, and zooming right in, other occupants of the building appear to be the U.S. Justice Dept (perhaps a Federal Court) and the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, etc. This structure appears to be connected to a larger L-shaped building.

comment_text: See the Richmond Planet. November 02, 1895, page 4, advertisement with portrait in column 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84025841/1895-11-02/ed-... The text of the advertisement reads, E. J. Crane PRACTICAL Watch-Maker and Jeweler The only Colored man In the South ever known to make a watch out and out. 20 years practical experience enables him to give perfect satisfac- tion in repairing Watches, Clocks, Jewelry E. J. CRANE, 122½ W. Broad St., Richmond. VA (Near Jefferson.) The 1xx block is still near Jefferson, but this number (or 122) no longer exists according to Google Maps. A number of buildings would have been demolished to build the theatre shown in: 2021 Streetview The theatre was opened in 1911. See va-rep.org/november.html

comment_text: According to www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1988-07-17-8801150659-... this mini-golf course was near Wacky Golf. Wacky Golf was at Highway 17 S and 29th Avenue, Myrtle Beach. According to htomc.dns2go.com/myrtle/minigolf.htm#HawVillage "Hawaiian Village: This course was originally Golden Dragon Golf, with a huge Buddha statue, owned by Mrs. Louna Massre. It was later re-themed as a Western/California Gold Rush era and renamed as Sutter's Mill Golf Mine; then later to the current Hawaiian theme. Some of the Old West elements, such as the caboose and the real antique steam locomotive were kept and redecorated." See 2019 Streetview of the Hawaiian Village course

comment_text: However, no sooner had I posted that than I found this: www.delcampe.net/fr/collections/cartes-postales/france/me... Note the rounded doorway and the large balconied building on the left, adjacent to the Tramu boutique, and then consider the view around the Place Saint Roch, up the Avenue Felix Faure in Menton: goo.gl/maps/w348nqw8xxR43p4f8 The shop on the corner is even still a perfumery! It's hard to see exactly the right angle up the road to the left of the perfume shop (Rue Partouneaux), but if you move around in streetview you can see the matching buildings.

comment_text: Still a hotel, now a Marriott. 2 New Montgomery Street, San Francisco, California 94105 See www.marriott.com/hotels/hotel-photos/sfolc-palace-hotel-a... August 2021 Streetview en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palace_Hotel,_San_Francisco "The Palace Hotel is a landmark historic hotel in San Francisco, California, located at the southwest corner of Market and New Montgomery streets. The hotel is also referred to as the "new" Palace Hotel to distinguish it from the original 1875 Palace Hotel, which had been demolished after being gutted by the fire caused by the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. The present structure opened on December 19, 1909, on the same site as its predecessor."

title: French at Krupp statue, Essen (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. French at Krupp statue, Essen [between ca. 1920 and ca. 1925] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards. Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Subjects: Essen Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. For more information, see George Grantham Bain Collection - Rights and Restrictions Information www.loc.gov/rr/print/res/274_bain.html Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print Part Of: Bain News Service photograph collection (DLC) 2005682517 General information about the George Grantham Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.35457 Call Number: LC-B2- 5919-6
comment_text: The picture shows the statue of Alfred Krupp outside the Marktkirche de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred-Krupp-Denkmal_an_der_Marktki... Using Google Translate: "Just three weeks after Alfred Krupp's death, on August 5, 1887, the Essen city council decided to erect a memorial to the deceased. It was created by the prominent sculptor Fritz Schaper on behalf of the city of Essen and was ceremoniously unveiled on July 14, 1889, the second anniversary of Alfred Krupp's death." "Until the end of World War II, the memorial remained virtually undamaged in its place, although around 90 percent of the inner city was destroyed by bombs in the aerial warfare. But after the time of National Socialism, Krupp's reputation declined because the company was now viewed critically as the “armory of the German Reich” under Kaiser Wilhelm II and Adolf Hitler. After the surrender, the statue was initially used by American press photographers as a backdrop, but strangers soon pushed it into one of the bomb craters surrounding it. It is unclear who recovered the bronze figure and the stone base, brought it to the factory site and stored it there. It is known that the memorial was re-erected in a residential area in 1952, one year after Alfred's imprisoned great-grandson, Alfred Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach, was released. The tensions between the city and the Krupp company gradually eased during the economic miracle, so that in the spring of 1961, on the occasion of the 150th anniversary of the Krupp company, the memorial was again displayed at the Marktkirche. However, it was not exactly at the previous location in the axis of Kettwiger Strasse, but to the west of the church, slightly covered by a tree." "After 61 years, in 2006, the Krupp memorial was moved to its original location." For a postcard showing the location as it would have been in 1923, see commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Marktkirche_Essen_um_1912... 360° view from 2016 showing location: goo.gl/maps/amkfyRQkkWU49fmH6

comment_text: de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaiser-Wilhelm-Denkmal_(Essen) Using Google Translate "After the foundation stone was laid on August 26, 1898 without a special celebration, the entire monument was inaugurated on October 23, 1898 in the middle of Burgplatz." "In the course of a comprehensive redesign of the inner city, an urban planning concept was sought in a first architecture competition in 1924 to redesign the Burgplatz in a big city. As a result, the area of the square, which had previously sloped to the east, was straightened and connected to Burgstrasse with a wide staircase. In 1928 the equestrian statue was finally moved to its current location on the southwestern edge of Burgplatz, near the Lichtburg building, directly on Burgstrasse, with a new, simplified base without a terrace." 2017 360° picture of statue in current location at goo.gl/maps/1RstDLe81X7KGhrHA

Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/stereo.1s08753 Call Number: LOT 13696, no. 3
comment_text: The recent improvement in image search has found this location for me (hey, artificial intelligence isn't all bad! 😄) According to a couple of sources this is Plaza de las Yerbas, now Parque Santander, in Bogota, Colombia: co.pinterest.com/pin/457959855832913776/ and about a third of the way down this page: mikesbogotablog.blogspot.com/2011/12/bogota-city-of-churc... The tower on the left is the Iglesia de la Orden Tercera, still there on the northern corner of the square: goo.gl/maps/Vyyj8Vnvrj79hRTb9 You can see the tower more clearly in this image which appears to have been taken at the same time as the LOC stereograph: twitter.com/colombia_hist/status/612622206191820800/photo/1 The building to the left with the belfry is the Church of Veracruz. It was destroyed in the earthquake of 1827 and rebuilt, with the present design dating from 1910. As you can see the picture on Twitter gives a date of 1887 for this image.

title: Identified! [Grace Coolidge and Oberlin president Henry Churchill King planting a tree at the Lincoln Memorial on Nov. 6, 1923, honoring the Oberlin Elm which had stood for over 200 years] (LOC)
description: Harris & Ewing,, photographer. [Grace Coolidge and Oberlin president Henry Churchill King planting a tree at the Lincoln Memorial on Nov. 6, 1923, honoring the Oberlin Elm which had stood for over 200 years] [6 November 1923] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller Notes: Title devised by Library staff. (Source: Flickr Commons project, 2020) Date based on date of negatives in same range. Gift; Harris & Ewing, Inc. 1955. Subjects: United States--District of Columbia--Washington (D.C.) Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. For more information, see Harris & Ewing Photographs - Rights and Restrictions Information www.loc.gov/rr/print/res/140_harr.html Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print Part Of: Harris & Ewing photograph collection (DLC) 2009632509 General information about the Harris & Ewing Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.hec Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/hec.31986 Call Number: LC-H27- A-7230
comment_text: Well, looks like her tree is still there at least: goo.gl/maps/omi79yMZqoHQWR6G8 Doesn't seem to be a suitably aged one on the equivalent corner on the north side, and the footpath is different there anyway, so I assume we are on the south side, even though things like footpaths can change easily. Seems she did a lot of tree planting: www.loc.gov/item/94509106/ Visible lettering on the banner says OBERI which doesn't seem to mean anything - probably another letter or two obscured.

comment_text: www.pjstar.com/article/20100617/NEWS/306179854 indicates that the Velvet Freeze name was dropped in 2010, but the East Peoria location re-opened using the Wonderdog name -- after a signature dish served at Velvet Freeze -- featured in window of this photo. More history at www.eastpeoriatimescourier.com/article/20100203/NEWS/3020... Now "The Original" Wonderdog -- www.facebook.com/originalwonderdog/ It looks as though Velvet Freeze may have moved from the location pictured here into the Fondulac Plaza, which is where the Original Wonderdog is now located. See 2018 Streetview. dfarq.homeip.net/velvet-freeze-history/ has information about the chain -- not this location.

Presumably en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aimé_Dupont "Aimé Dupont (6 December 1841 – 16 February 1900) was a Belgian-born American sculptor and photographer who was best known for his pictures of opera singers when he was the official photographer for the Metropolitan Opera in New York City." I think the building on this photo is the Mehmaan Khana, because the Yamuna river is visible on the left, s. Streetview Photo of the Mehmaan Khana by Saumil Shah: www.flickr.com/photos/saumil/6855348955/ The Kau Ban Mosque: goo.gl/maps/XJtc696zX8bMR7Jc9 Photo by BoblyP: www.flickr.com/photos/boblyp/36005086884/

comment_text: This is actually "Crafton" not Grafton - Pennsylvania, a neighborhood of Pittsburgh. Building still stands at corner of E Crafton and Noble Aves Geotag: 40.435758, -80.064720 Streetview: goo.gl/maps/mEgRkLt5XYqSUzow6 The Boggs & Buhl department store led me to Pittsburgh then a little googling got me to the Grafton-Crafton label mistake. Then I followed an old streetcar map around Crafton till i found the corner.

comment_text: See www.findagrave.com/memorial/45335129/margaret-ida-dahms "Margaret Ida Wendlund and Leonard A. Dahms were married February 8, 1942 in Blue Hill, Nebraska. She and her husband made their home in Blue Hill, Nebraska where she raised large gardens and had chickens. She cleaned and sold the chickens to the workers of the Ammunition Depot at Hastings. In 1960, they moved back to Arapahoe, Nebraska. They bought the Dairy Queen in Arapahoe, Nebraska and renamed it Dahms Drive-In. She continued to run it for more than 40 years." The sign was still there in 2012. See Streetview 2012

comment_text: I found two discussions about Chicken in the Rough: forums.roadfood.com/Chicken-In-the-Rough-m20494.aspx www.facebook.com/groups/324178994291839/permalink/8559848... The second included comments that indicated that a sign for the restaurant near New Market was still there. That led me to this Streetview from 2018. It seems to be a sign from Chicken in the Rough, but not the one Margolies photographed in 1982. One commenter said that the restaurant had been part of M.D's Modern Cabins and burned. For a postcard promoting M.D's, see www.hippostcard.com/listing/postcard-va-new-market-m-ds-m... or www.rubylane.com/item/398016-6381/1940x27s-Mid-Century-Po...

comment_text: Oct. 1, 1921. Columbia 7, Amherst 9 Prior to 1928 Football games at Columbia were played on the south lawn in front of Low Memorial Library (partially visible on left of pic). The dome center left is St. Pauls Chapel with Buell Hall (still the oldest building on the campus) in front of it by the flag pole. The larger buildings center right are Kent Hall (left) and Hamilton Hall (right) and a little bit of Hartley Hall is visible far right. All still standing. Current Street View

comment_text: www.mcmenamins.com/elks-temple "The Elks Temple was built in the second Renaissance Revival style in 1915-16 when fraternal organizations were an important part of the community and had the money to build beautiful buildings such as this one. It was designed by É. Frère Champney, a graduate of the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. It is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places." Oct 2018 Streetview shows it under reconstruction.

comment_text: 2022 E. Colfax Ave, Denver, CO 80206 lionslairco.com/about "The Lion’s Lair is Denver’s oldest consistently operating independent music venue, beginning as the Playboy Club in the 1930s, then the Aladdin Lounge from 1936 until 1967 when it was bought and rechristened after then-owner Jim Lyons. In its current iteration the Lair has been providing live music to the city of Denver since the early ‘90s." Streetview 2018

comment_text: cinematreasures.org/theaters/13470 615 N. Manhattan Avenue, Manhattan, KS 66502 "The Miller Theater opened on May 1, 1926. The opening movie was “Paris at Midnight” with Lionel Barrymore. On August 26, 1930 it was renamed Varsity Theater, and on February 25, 1936 under new owners was renamed Sonsa Theater. On May 23, 1951 it became the Campus Theater. In the late-1990’s the Campus Theater was purchased by Carmike. The Campus Theater was closed in 1998, and was taken over by the adjacent Varney’s Bookstore. That closed in 2016, and it has now gone into other retail use." Streetview 2018

comment_text: cinematreasures.org/theaters/23 Boston Opera House 539 Washington Street, Boston, MA 02111 "The B.F. Keith Memorial Theatre was a vaudeville house in Boston’s theater district. It opened on October 29, 1928 with the film “Oh Kay” starring Colleen Moore. This beautiful house later became part of the RKO theater chain and the RKO Keith’s switched to a movies only format. Its name was later changed to the Savoy Theatre and was purchased by Sack Theatres. In 1978, the Savoy Theatre was sold by Sack to the Opera Company of Boston, and the theater became known as the Opera House, for which it was used until 1990. The theater was renovated, restored, and reopened in July 2004 by Clear Channel Entertainment, and is now a site for touring Broadway shows and other live entertainment, known as the Boston Opera House." Streetview 2018

comment_text: Streetview 2018 From registration for Downtown Historic District [ www.historycolorado.org/sites/default/files/media/documen... ] "105 E. Main St., 5FN.2284, Dr. Morgan Office, ca. 1927 (Photograph 37) This plain, one-story brown brick building with flat roof has some characteristics of the Mediterranean Revival style. The front façade (south side) has a central entrance with brick arch and inset wood door with three stepped lights. Flanking the entrance are flat arch plate-glass windows with brick sills. There is a center flat parapet above the entrance and projecting piers at each end of the wall. Between the piers and the parapet are slanting bands of metal tile. At the top and bottom of the wall are contrasting courses of red brick. Alterations. A 1981 survey photo shows the same door but the window openings have glass block; neither are believed to be original. The date the original windows and door were removed is unknown. Historic Background. A previous building on this site was removed by 1926, when Sanborn maps show the parcel to be vacant. The current building is shown on a 1949 map. In 1955, Dr. A.W. Morgan, an osteopath and surgeon, had his office here and in 1957, Bramer & Tull Optometrists were located here. In 1964, the Florence Chamber of Commerce had offices here, and Anthony Scutti was the secretary and manager for the organization. The 1981 survey found that the building was used as an annex of the First National Bank of Florence. Rocky Mountain Bank & Trust began utilizing the building in the early 2000s. "

comment_text: There was a "Colonial Theatre" in the nearby Seaside Park, on the southwest corner of Stockton Avenue and Boulevard, s. books.google.ch/books?id=hI-HGsD1oocC&pg=PA51#v=onepa.... A comment in cinematreasures.org/theaters/15534 states that it was remodeled in 1937, closed in August 1973 and demolished on July 28, 1981 to make way for the construction of 11 townhouses. This is certainly the same theatre, which stood here (see the houses in the background).

comment_text: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Post_Office_(Michigan_City,_Indiana) "Michigan City Post Office is a historic post office building located at Michigan City, LaPorte County, Indiana. It was designed by the Office of the Supervising Architect under James Knox Taylor and built in 1909. It is a one-story, Georgian Revival style brick and limestone building. It has a hipped roof behind a balustraded parapet and basement. A rear addition was built in 1926, and expanded in 1963. It housed a post office until 1973." 126 E 5th Street, Michigan City, IN Some historical photographs are provided by current occupants: www.braje-nelson.com/history-of-our-building/ 2016 Streetview

comment_text: Superior Court of County of Santa Barbara, California 1100 Anacapa St. 2018 Streetview From www.santabarbaraca.gov/services/community/historic/hpwa/d... " Designation Status: Designated City Landmark Assessor Parcel Number: 029-161-001 Historic Name: County Courthouse Constructed: 1927-1929 Property Description: The Santa Barbara Courthouse is situated on an entire block within the downtown core of the city, a site of 450 feet by 450 feet for a total of 4.65 acres, and lushly landscaped with a wide variety of trees, shrubs, climbing vines, and flowers. A number of the mature trees on site were planted when the building was dedicated in 1929. The majority of the landscaping is contained within a semi-formal garden that frames a series of terraced lawn areas approaching the west façade where a public stage provides an outdoor performance venue. The landscape architect designed this series of terraced lawns to provide for public presentations, gatherings, community functions, debates and civic interaction. Among the plantings are 57 varieties of palms, Coast Redwoods (Sequoia Sempervirens), Saucer Magnolia (Magnolia X Soulangiana), and Giant Sequoia (Sequoiadendron Giganteum). The general design and layout of the courthouse follow a modified Spanish castle plan. The building is placed on the site so the most important rooms face south for natural heat gain to warm these spaces. There are many castle defensive elements used on the Santa Barbara County Courthouse. The architect used these Andalusian-Spanish castle elements as metaphorical connections to the Spanish roots of Santa Barbara and many of the design details are also metaphoric of castle defense elements. The courthouse is the seat of government for Santa Barbara County, much like a castle is the seat of its ruler. The courthouse complex is comprised of four buildings connected by either a bridge or arch, taking an overall form much like a capital "L." Because these buildings were constructed at the same time and are interconnected by arches and bridges, they are considered one building for the purpose of the National Historic Landmark designation. The main façade of the building that faces Anacapa Street (south) stretches across the site some 370 feet. The Figueroa Street façade (east) is 356 feet and the Santa Barbara Street façade (north) is 161 feet. The building height varies from 40 feet up to 111 feet. The site changes in elevation by as much as four feet, dropping to the East. The sunken gardens drop below the level of the main arch entry paving by six feet. The general "L" shape of the building protects the garden (also called a "bailey," in castle terms). The clock tower observation deck (El Mirador or "keep," in castle terms) rises 88 feet above the ground entry level. This height provides the best defensive vantage point across the garden, the main entrance, and outer points in the approach of the courthouse. The Rotunda, located at the intersection of the Anacapa and Figueroa wings, provides access to the alarm bell located at the outside southeast corner of the building. The northeast corner of the courthouse is defended by means of a turret with lancets, machicolations and embrasures. Architect: William Moser and William Moser, Jr. Architectural Style: Spanish Colonial Revival Property Type: Courthouse Original Use: courthouse "

"Old City Hall - 1924 - In 1923, voters approved a bond issue for Riverside to construct its first municipality owned city hall. Constructed in the Spanish colonial revival style, this structure served the city government until 1975. Sold by the city in 1976. The building was used for commercial purposes until 1985, when it was purchased and restored by the partnership of Jlubik Marp and Coil local citizens." [Note: I'm not sure all the names were transcribed correctly, but Coil is still connected to the building. See www.pe.com/2013/07/11/riverside-tilden-coil-wins-prestigi...]

comment_text: 237 North Main Street Streetview 2017 "Hieronymus Mueller built a new 3-story building at 237 North Main Street in Decatur to house his plumbing business. This business was sold by the Muellers in 1896 and the building was sold to the Herald Newspaper. The historic building still stands today with the designation of “Herald Block, 1891” in its cornice. It was originally the “Mueller Block, 1891”." muellermuseum.org/plant-office-locations/

comment_text: 210 Main Street Streetview 2018 "210 Main Street - Bickel Insurance and Real Estate (McLaughlin Building) ... A building was re-built on the site in 1911 and housed a barber shop and Oehring’s Jewelry, with McLaughton’s law offices upstairs. The name of James McLaughton is still displayed at the top of the building. Later the building housed Northwest Bell Telephone, Underkofer’s Drug Store, M. X. Geske Attorney, a beauty shop, and Red Shriver’s Barber Shop. Present owners Dan and Marsha Bickel operate Bickel Insurance and Security Loan here. ..." www.visitiowa.org/uploads/PDF_File_5918506.pdf p. 20

comment_text: See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Co-operative_Publishing_Company_Bui... "The Co-operative Publishing Company Building is a historic building in Guthrie, Oklahoma, that is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The building was the home of the State Capitol newspaper from 1902 to 1911, and it replaced another building on the same site, which the paper had been using since 1890." "In 1975, the building was acquired by the Oklahoma Historical Society, who had plans to outfit it as a publishing museum. The State Capital Publishing Museum opened in 1983. In the 1990s and again in the 2000s, budget cuts led to the trimming of staff and programs at the museum, and unexpected building-maintenance problems in 2012 led to a decision to close the museum indefinitely. As of 2016, the museum has remained closed since 2012." 2016 Streetview

comment_text: Streetview 2012 LoC has a photo of this arch in the HABS collection. www.loc.gov/pictures/item/mt0111.photos.100199p/ "1. EAST FACADE OF THE MARCUS DALY HOTEL. THE HOTEL WAS CONSTRUCTED IN A U SHAPE, WITH THE ENTRANCE ARCADE FORMING THE FORTH SIDE OF THE RECTANGLE - Anaconda Historic District, Marcus Daly Hotel, 200-208 Main Street, Anaconda, Deer Lodge County, MT " History is at www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/hh/item/mt0111/ "The construction of the Montana Hotel (renamed The Marcus Daly Hotel) was begun in 1888 by the Montana Hotel Association. It was completed in the spring of 1889 at an estimated cost of $125,000. Designed by Chicago Architect W.W. Boyington, this building was heavily financed by Marcus Daly, mining magnate and patron of the Smelter City. Using a composite style of French Renaissance and Romanesque architecture, the hotel was a 120 feet square, four story structure built of local red brick with terra cotta ornamentation. The building sits 10 feet back from the Main Street sidewalk and features a 34 foot wide central arched entrance resting on terra cotta columns with a pediment above. The hotel interior included a full basement equipped with a servant's dining room, a laundry, boilers, and a dynamo for electric light generation. The first and second floors, finished in red oak and eastern pine, contained the main dining room, a ladies' ordinary, billiard hall, drug store, and barber shop. After Marcus Daly died in 1900, the Montana Hotel underwent extensive remodeling, costing $96,000 under the ownership of the Anaconda Company. In 1954, the building was purchased by Edison and Bell, Inc. of Kalispell, MT. The firm operated the hotel until 1959 at which time plans for demolition were considered. To combat this action, citizens of Anaconda formed the Montana Hotel Corporation and purchased the structure, renaming it the Marcus Daly Hotel. A restoration project was undertaken in 1964 and a modern motel unit was built to the rear of the original structure. In 1975, heavy financial burdens and potential bankruptcy faced the Montana Hotel Corporation and the building was sold to a local developer in 1976. An aggressive program of structural renovation was begun, including the removal of the hotel's two upper stories. The remaining space will be used for retail and office space."

title: Bijapur, India - Mosque of Ibrahim Rozza (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Bijapur, India - Mosque of Ibrahim Rozza [between ca. 1915 and ca. 1920] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Photograph shows the Ibrahim Rauza, the tomb of Ibrahim Adil Shah II (1556-1627). Title from data provided by the Bain News Service on the negative. Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. For more information, see George Grantham Bain Collection - Rights and Restrictions Information www.loc.gov/rr/print/res/274_bain.html Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print Part Of: Bain News Service photograph collection (DLC) 2005682517 General information about the George Grantham Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.31857 Call Number: LC-B2- 5381-2
comment_text: "Ibrahim Rauza (‘Rauza’ means “tomb”) also known as Ali Rauza, built in 1627, contains the tomb of Ibrahim Adil Shah II and his queen Taj Sultana." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bijapur_Fort#Ibrahim_Rauza "Ibrahim Rauza consists of two core constructions: a tomb and a mosque with several smaller structures. All these buildings are built within a square enclosure with an attractive garden in the front. Both the structures are built on a platform that is 360 feet long and 160 feet wide, around a walled enclosure." www.talkativeman.com/ibrahim-rauza-bijapur/ The Bain photo shows the mosque: Street View 2014 See also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibrahim_Adil_Shah_II

comment_text: Street View 2013 "319 Court Street (GA03-227) This two-story stucco building is identified as the A.J. Hale building. Hale was a local attorney who came to Beatrice in the 1870s and opened a law firm. After building this property and practicing for a few years, he left Beatrice in 1886 to return to Nebraska City where he remained a gentleman farmer supplementing his income with a sizable inheritance. It has display windows on either side of a recessed entry and a glass transom above as part of its storefront. Two identifiable window fenestrations are blocked over with stucco on the second story and a decorative gabled cornice with brackets and finials finishes the façade. The building name is integrated under the gabled cornice between the two center brackets. The building was constructed in 1886. An original bay window was removed in the early 1980s after structural failure. Everett Druggists and Sundries was the main commercial occupant of this building during its renovation in the 1960s." www.nps.gov/nr/feature/places/pdfs/16000481.pdf

comment_text: street view 2012 www.google.com/maps/@38.1298005,-87.9327842,3a,75y,357.36... "Originally built by the Harmonists as the fourth and last dormitory, it was completed shortly before they departed New Harmony in 1824. The Owen-Maclure community used the space for a variety of purposes from a multi-family dwelling, to a warehouse, to a venue for hosting lectures and dances. In 1859, the structure was purchased by the New Harmony Dramatic Association and renamed Union Hall. The building was transformed into a theater and was home to a famous local acting company, the Golden Troupe. In 1888, Eugene Thrall became the sole owner and the theater was renamed Thrall’s Opera House. For a short time from 1911 to 1913, the Opera House was a nickelodeon movie house until it was purchased in 1914 and turned into a gas station and garage. In 1964, the space was purchased by the Harmonie Associates, who persuaded the state of Indiana to purchase, restore, and maintain the site." visitnewharmony.com/playexplore_cpt/thralls-opera-house/ " When the opera house was first constructed in 1824, it wasn't an opera house at all. It was a communal building created by the Harmonists, the religious group that founded New Harmony, to house single people that wanted to come and live in the Harmonist utopia. The building was the fourth such communal building, and the last building that the Harmonists built in New Harmony before selling the town and moving out to Pennsylvania. Over the next few decades, the building housed a number of different businesses, including a Sunday school, a store, and a warehouse. In 1859 it was purchased by the New Harmony Dramatic Association for use as a theater and dance hall. Various theatrical groups, like New Harmony's famous Golden Troupe, used the theater to stage their productions. Eugene S. Thrall, a man who had been co-owner of the building since 1867, bought out the rest of it in 1888 and remolded the front, adding the opera house styled facade you see today. He also changed the name of the building to Thrall's Opera House. It was used as an opera house until 1910, after which it was used the next few decades as a nickelodeon movie house and a Conoco gas station. In 1964 the Indiana Department of Natural Resources bought the building, thanks to the efforts of the Harmonie Associates, renovated it to be used as a theater once again. Thrall's Opera House still hosts various musical productions on its stage, as well as workshops, lectures, and balls. Visitors can go to the opera house and marvel at the style of its auditorium room, which harkens back to late 19th-century America." www.theclio.com/web/entry?id=23565

Some history is at blog.firsttries.com/ford-building-and-crescent-ballroom/. This post suggests that part of the building is used as a warehouse.

comment_text: Photo of James M. Cox, Democratic Party nominee for President in 1920, leading a parade on 42nd Street (Manhattan) from west to east, as he approaches the intersection of Madison Avenue and 42nd. The photographer's perspective is from the north side of the intersection on Madison Avenue, looking toward 42nd St. to the southwest and Cox as he approaches the intersection. The Union Carbon and Carbide Building Union Carbide and Carbon Building (built in 1913, demolished in 2001) serves as the backdrop for the scene. Here's a rough approximation of the view today, via Google Street View: www.google.com/maps/@40.7528447,-73.9792767,3a,75y,270h,9... [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog]

title: Inaugurating Nonin-Basha Bridge, Osaka (LOC)

Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. For more information, see George Grantham Bain Collection - Rights and Restrictions Information www.loc.gov/rr/print/res/274_bain.html Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print Part Of: Bain News Service photograph collection (DLC) 2005682517 General information about the George Grantham Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.30994 Call Number: LC-B2- 5259-16
comment_text: Osaka appears to have 808 bridges. See www.city.osaka.lg.jp/kensetsu/cmsfiles/contents/0000042/4... www.geocaching.com/geocache/GC312HN_noninbashi-pedestrian... suggests that it (or more likely its replacement) is a "huge pedestrian bridge constructed under the highway." One of the comments says "What a huge intersection with the longest pedestrian bridge ever" and has a photo of the location in 2017. www.city.osaka.lg.jp/contents/wdu020/enjoy/en/overview/pd... has a map that shows the location of today's Nonin Bridge. It's roughly in the center of the map, crossing the Higashi-Yokobori river. The intersection is of Matsuyamachi Avenue and Chuo-odori Street. It's also a highway intersection. See goo.gl/maps/WqBEa8tMn9k

comment_text: According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elwood_Bar the address would have been 2100 Woodward Avenue. Also from the Wikipedia article, the building has been moved. "In 1997, construction of Comerica Park (the Detroit Tigers stadium) threatened the Elwood, and the Bar was moved to its present location at 300 East Adams Street (on the corner of Adams and Brush). The building underwent a complete restoration at that time, and is now open as "Elwood Bar and Grill," catering to visitors attending games at the nearby Comerica Park and Ford Field." See www.elwoodgrill.com/ Streetview

comment_text: This photo was taken in Norwood, Ohio. It looks like a cataloging mistake, as the subject heading references Ohio, while the main title references California. The Routes 22 and 3 referenced are U.S. Rt. 22, and Ohio Rt. 3. This building, the Mitchel Block , was at 4943-5 Montgomery Ave. (presently Montgomery St.). It no longer seems to be standing. www.google.com/maps/@39.1649161,-84.4541766,3a,71.8y,351....

comment_text: Unlike the famously durable locations across the lake in Lake Placid and Lake George, NY this was one of the corporate-owned locations that closed right away not long after this pic. The building was heavily remodeled by a subsequent restaurant which stood abandoned for years, surviving just long enough for the first, 2007, Google Streetview pass before being replaced by the inevitable chain drugstore. www.google.com/maps/@44.4569071,-73.2085131,3a,75y,117.38...

comment_text: "The Santa Fe Diner is another Valentine diner. This one was originally installed in 1950 as the "Birth Place Diner" since it was located on the site of Winslow's first dwelling. At that point, there was a small stork on the roof and it was known as the Stork Cafe. The diner was also known as the "One Spot Grill". An awning and a canopy connecting it to the adjacent building were installed. Since this photo from 2004, the diner was moved to Sultan, WA." www.roadarch.com/diners/az.html It was here, and is now there.

comment_text: They are lined up outside the Hippodrome in New York, where the production is "Happy Days", an extravaganza with swimmers and elephants. Alexander Woolcott' review: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D01E4D6133DE5... It opened on August 23, 1919, was interrupted by the actors' strike until September 1, and continued until May 15, 1920. www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/happy-days-6673 The care has a 1919 license plate: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_New_... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Hippodrome Location in Nov. 2016 Google Street View, Avenue of the Americas (6th Ave, btwn 43rd and 44th Sts. www.google.com/maps/place/1120+6th+Ave,+New+York,+NY+1003...

comment_text: The Chambers and Madison Streets streetcar line (aka Madison Street line) of the New York Railways was discontinued on Sept. 21, 1919. Cars on this line were battery powered. metro.wikia.com/wiki/List_of_streetcar_lines_in_Manhattan. This line ran east to west from the Grand St. Ferry on the East River to the Chambers St. Ferry on the Hudson, roughly on the route of the present day M22 bus line. books.google.com/books?id=2DA05tBefEsC&pg=PA888&l... metro.wikia.com/wiki/List_of_streetcar_lines_in_Manhattan It's possible this photo was taken to illustrate a story about the last day of the line's service. The streetcar is pictured traveling through the archway in Manhattan's Municipal Building on Centre Street and Chambers. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan_Municipal_Building Street view (east through arch), June 1916: www.google.com/maps/place/Avenue+of+the+Finest,+New+York,... account of controversial closing of east side lines, NYT 9/19/19: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A04E6D9153AE0...

title: Pershing parade (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Pershing parade [1919 September 10] (date taken or published later by Bain) 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards. Photo shows parade in New York where General John J. Pershing lead WWI veterans (Source: New York Times, Sept. 10, 1919) Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.29390 Call Number: LC-B2- 5019-8
comment_text: Pershing Leads WWI Victory Parade "On September 10, 1919, nearly a year after World War I ended, Gen. John J. Pershing led a victory parade down New York City’s Fifth Avenue. Vast crowds cheered as 25,000 U.S. soldiers who had served in the American Expeditionary Force’s 1st Division on the Western Front marched from 107th Street to Washington Square in Greenwich Village, wearing trench helmets and full combat gear.'New York lived yesterday probably the last chapter in its history of great military spectacles growing out of the war,' The New York Times reported. The loudest cheers were for Pershing, who, according to the Times, 'was kept at almost continual salute by the tributes volleyed at him from both sides of the avenue.'"By the time an armistice was declared on Nov. 11, 1918, more than 2 million American soldiers had served on the battlefields of Western Europe. Roughly 50,000 of them were killed in action. "In September 1919, Congress authorized President Woodrow Wilson to promote Pershing, the commander of the expeditionary force, to the rank of General of the Armies of the United States. He remains the sole person to be promoted in his own lifetime to the highest rank in the U.S. Army. "Congress also authorized Pershing to create his own insignia. He chose to wear four gold stars for the rest of his career, which meant he outranked subsequent Army chiefs of staff, who wore four silver stars, and even the five-star General of the Army insignias worn during World War II by George Marshall, Douglas MacArthur and Dwight Eisenhower. "Pershing led a similar victory parade down Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington on Sept. 17. On Sept. 19, he addressed a joint session of the Congress. He died in 1948 at age 87." Sources: The New York Times; History.com – Andrew Glass, Politico Street view (2016) 5th Avenue at West 14th St

comment_text: at, 11 Place de Etats Unis, per books.google.com/books?id=jWzAAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA13&dq... From AMERICAN FOOTPRINTS IN PARIS by FRANCOIS BOUCHER Published 1921 "At No. 11 of the Place is the Hotel Bischoffsheim, home of M. and Mme. Francis de Croisset, where President Wilson stayed during his second residence in Paris for the work of the Peace Conference, after his return from the United States, the 14th March, 1919, until the 28th June of the same year. In the study which he used there, several meetings of the "Four" took place (President Wilson, Clemenceau, Lloyd George, Orlando). " archive.org/stream/americanfootprin017388mbp#page/n51/mod... The building today, repurposed as a museum: www.google.com/maps/place//@48.8678509,2.2939132,3a,104y,...

comment_text: This building from 1560 was standing at the 'rue de la Croix d'Or', s. argueyr.perso.sfr.fr/Famille_Bosler/Maisons_Bosler_de_Ret... p. 11 and photo p. 12 "A l'autre coin de la rue de la Croix d'Or se trouva it une très ancienne maison de Rethel, le magasin "Au bon Diable" qui datait de 1560." The street 'rue de la Croix d'Or' does not exist anymore, it was destroyed in a big fire on September 1, 1914, s argueyr.perso.sfr.fr/Famille_Bosler/Maisons_Bosler_de_Ret... pages 4 & 5, and this part of the town was apparently rebuilt based on a completely new plan, s. www.google.com/maps/place/49%C2%B030'38.2%22N+4%C2%B022'0...

title: Peace Hurrah (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Peace Hurrah 1918 Nov. 11 (date created or published later by Bain) 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title and date from data provided by the Bain News Service on the negative. comment_text: I don't think this is Radna, Slovenia. That village would be too small IMO, s. streetview: goo.gl/maps/NtxC2Y1RAuy I assume that it's Radna, a quarter of Lipova. "Lipova is a town in Romania, Arad County, located in the Banat region of western Transylvania. ... . It administers two villages, Radna (Máriaradna) and Șoimoș (Solymosvár), and its total surface is 134.6 square km." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lipova,_Arad Radna is on the other side of the river. This could be the steeple visible in the photo (with a new top): goo.gl/maps/rSGfK5usGS82 (streetview 2012). Unfortunately no streetview in that street.

comment_text: This looks like the north gate of Gramercy Park at Lexington and E. 21st, and is probably connected to the adjacent photos of the May, 1918 charity garden party. She appears to be giving out muffins to kids. Mary Boland isn''t mentioned in the articles I've found about the event. www.google.com/maps/@40.7382369,-73.9857397,3a,75y,132.17...

comment_text: I think the building behind the clock is still there. See streetview at www.google.com/maps/@40.7646991,-73.9727144,3a,75y,22.02h... That building is at the northeast corner of the intersection of Fifth Avenue and East 60th Street. That means the photo is taken from somewhere near the Plaza Hotel. The building with the large Red Cross flag must be where the Sherry-Netherland Building (built in 1927) now is. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sherry-Netherland The Wikipedia article indicates that the site had previously been occupied by the New Netherland Hotel. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotel_New_Netherland For more about the New Netherlands Hotel, see daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2014/07/the-lost-new-nethe...

(in German) The camp existed from September 1914 until 1921. It hosted 10000 - 15000 prisoners, mostly Russians.

title: Happy 8th Birthday, Flickr Commons! 4 days to go (LOC)
description: Happy 8th Birthday, Flickr Commons! 4 days to go (LOC) The Commons has connected us all so well to a bounty of historic photo collections that we’ve selected glorious pictures of bridges to count down to the Jan. 16th official anniversary. Please celebrate with us and explore the infinite possibilities of the Commons. Pick your 8 favorite photos and tag them “Happy Birthday Flickr Commons.” Or, make a gallery and share the link here. title: Wrecked Zeppelin from plane in Eng. [i.e. England] (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Wrecked Zeppelin from plane in Eng. [i.e. England] [between ca. 1915 and ca. 1920] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from data provided by the Bain News Service on the negative. Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.25882 Call Number: LC-B2- 4442-7
comment_text: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Zeppelins has a list of Zeppelins and identifies those that landed or were brought down in England. Candidates wrecked before late 1917 are L48. But the CPI picture doesn’t match the location shown in www.nzhistory.net.nz/media/photo/zeppelin-wreck, with a picture of the June 16/17, 1917 wreck of L48. SL11 crashed at Cuffley, Hertfordshire,. Night of 2/3 September 1916 — first success in bringing a Zeppelin down. L31 -- crashed and landed on an oak tree, near Potters Bar. 2 October 1916. There is no oak tree in this picture. L32 was brought down on September 24, 1916 near Snail’s Farm, South Green, Great Burstead, Essex. Came down in flames. This seems to show the shape of the craft more than one burned would do. See twitter.com/adie1412/status/569584798643183617 for a photo that purports to be of L32. L33 landed in Little Wigborough, Essex, near New Hall Farm. September 24, 1916. Crew attempted to burn the craft, but unsuccessfully. www.google.com/maps/place/New+Hall+Bungalow,+Copt+Hall+Ln... is certainly similar terrain and descriptions suggest that it was in two fields. See www.tollesburyazaz.fsnet.co.uk/News/March02/Wigborough.htm. Strongest candidate, I believe. For more, see: www.essex.police.uk/museum/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/7.pdf article on “Somewhere over Essex: The Zeppelin Raids on Essex.” www.historyhouse.co.uk/articles/zeppelins.html blackmorehistory.blogspot.com/2008/08/zeppelins-over-esse...

comment_text: Mislabeled as British Embassy, but actually (former Treasury Secretary) Francis MacVeigh's mansion on 16th St. N.W., which he loaned to the arriving British War Commission as its residence. In 1921, Mexico purchased it as its embassy and altered the entry by adding a portico. It is now the Mexican Cultural Institute. A detachment of cavalry escorted Balfour to the 16th Street home of Franklin MacVeagh, where he was to stay during the war conference. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9405E2DA153AE4... "PROVIDE MILITARY ESCORT Two Troops of Second Cavalry to Lead the Parade at Washington. Military Escort at Capital. Greetings at the Station. BALFOUR PARTY IN CAPITAL TODAY" query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D01E5D9153AE433A... He arrived on April 22, 1917 "CHEERING THOUSANDS GREET BALFOUR; ALL WASHINGTON OUT FOR WELCOME; HERE NOT TO SUGGEST BUT TO INFORM US; GREETING SURPRISES VISITOR "It Has All Been Very Moving," Mr. Balfour's Comment on Welcome. CAPITAL GAY WITH FLAGS Mounted Troops Guard the Distinguished Guest in Parade Through the Streets." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9904EED9123BEE3AB... History of the building: www.instituteofmexicodc.org/mansion.php www.embassy.org/gallery/historical/history001.html June 2014 Google Street View www.google.com/maps/@38.925552,-77.036467,3a,75y,91.9h,90... www.google.com/maps/@38.925883,-77.036518,3a,75y,146.54h,...

comment_text: The number scratched out indicates it was originally cataloged near other Bain pictures of the Citizen's Preparedness Parade, held on May 13, 1916. The negative and label are dated then as well. A photo with the same caption, taken from around 39th St. and Fifth Ave,, looking northeast. The street sign in this one (W., 37th Street) indicates that it was taken a few blocks south of the other. The buildings on the east side of 5th, between 37th and 38th, were still there last September: www.google.com/maps/@40.750238,-73.983257,3a,75y,57h,101....

comment_text: Still around, and a Grade II listed building: "Town hall. 1882. By JB Pearce after a competition. Red brick laid in Flemish bond and with terracotta details and sandstone dressings. Slate roofs. Built round a narrow courtyard. Queen Anne style. EXTERIOR: 2 storeys rising to 3 in the tower. Asymmetrical entrance front to the north-west. 7-window range. Rusticated ground floor and string courses between the floors. To the left are 3 bays of cross casements fitted with plate-glass horned sashes. The first-floor windows have 2 transoms. Small pediments in the balustraded parapet. These bays have paired pilasters right and left. The centre bay has one 3-light cross casement (with sashes) to each of its 3 floors. The right-hand 3 bays contain the round-arched principal entrance and two 2-light cross casements as before. Paired pilasters separate the first-floor cross casements which have the double transoms and now round heads. Swags in the parapet. A tower, square on plan, rises through 2 storeys to an ogeed lantern: open round arches over clock faces; glazed lantern. The south-west facade faces the river: symmetrical; 8 bays plus closing bays right and left. Cross casements fitted with sashes as before. Garlanded parapet and central segmental pediment. Hipped roofs with flat. INTERIOR: the entrance hall has pairs of panelled baluster piers on high plinths alternating with single piers running down the centre and attached as pilasters to the walls. Modified Ionic capitals. An Imperial staircase rises to the east: open string, twisted balusters over vases, moulded handrail. Pairs of painted glass windows light the stairs from a small internal courtyard. The whole of the west side of the first floor is given over to a ceremonial hall of 9 by 3 bays, the bays divided by fluted pilasters. The north wall has paired fluted columns and pilasters, the south wall has Corinthian columns set in front of pilasters. Heavy modillion cornice with leaf-trail decoration and deep coving below a barrel-vaulted roof with eared and shouldered raised panels. The south-east corner of the first floor was used until 1990 as a magistrates court with a complete set of fittings from 1882. Panelled bench and dock, the latter with an internal staircase dropping to a secure room and side entrance on the ground floor. The council chamber has a canopy at the west end and a gallery at the east end. " list.english-heritage.org.uk/resultsingle.aspx?uid=1246969 Full restoration in 2008: archiseek.com/2009/1878-municipal-buildings-great-yarmout... 2012 Google Street View: www.google.com/maps/@52.606173,1.724362,3a,75y,118.9h,100...

comment_text: "The Rufus Stone A stone known as the "Rufus Stone" (at grid reference SU270124) marks a spot where William II [commonly known as William Rufus or William the Red] supposedly fell . The claim that this is the location of his death appears to date from no earlier than a 17th-century visit by Charles II to the forest. At the time the most popular account of William's death involved the fatal arrow deflecting off a tree, and Charles II appears to have been shown a suitable tree. Letters in The Gentleman's Magazine reported that the tree was cut down and burned during the 18th century. Later in that century the Rufus stone was set up. Originally it was around 5 feet 10 inches tall (1.78 m) with a stone ball on top. King George III visited the stone in 1789, along with his queen, and an inscription was added to the stone to commemorate the visit. It was protected with a cast iron cover in 1841 after repeated vandalism. The inscription on the Rufus Stone reads: Here stood the oak tree, on which an arrow shot by Sir Walter Tyrrell at a stag, glanced and struck King William the Second, surnamed Rufus, on the breast, of which he instantly died, on the second day of August, anno 1100. King William the Second, surnamed Rufus, being slain, as before related, was laid in a cart, belonging to one Purkis and drawn from hence, to Winchester, and buried in the Cathedral Church, of that city." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_II_of_England#The_Rufus_Stone Google Street View, 2011: www.google.com/maps/@50.911403,-1.616883,3a,75y,215.68h,7...

comment_text: "The Royal Yacht Squadron is one of the most prestigious yacht clubs in the world. Its clubhouse is Cowes Castle on the Isle of Wight in the United Kingdom. Member yachts are given the Suffix RYS to their names, and permitted to fly the White Ensign of the Royal Navy[1] rather than the merchant Red Ensign flown by the majority of other UK registered vessels. The club's patron is Queen Elizabeth II and the club's admiral is Prince Philip who is also a former club commodore." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Yacht_Squadron A history of the castle: www.rys.org.uk/about/cowes-castle/ 2009 street view: www.google.com/maps/@50.76616,-1.300434,3a,75y,344.32h,86...

comment_text: Street view 2009: www.google.com/maps/@50.765551,-1.299656,3a,75y,162.63h,8... "The 200-year-old Drover’s Marine Hotel, later the Royal Marine Hotel, was one of the most prestigious in Cowes. Its guest book reads like a Who’s Who of European Royalty. In its hey-day it was the place in Cowes to stay for the summer yachting season. Now known as Marine Court and converted into apartments and offices there are few traces of its earlier elegance" (www.ghostisland.com/content/documents/cowesghostmap.pdf)

comment_text: "Erected in 1887 to mark the 50th year of Queen Victoria's reign the Jubilee Clock was originally positioned on a stone base on Weymouth sands, but in the 1920s the Esplanade was built around it to protect the sands from the encroachment of shingle from the eastern end of the beach. The clock is one of Weymouth's best-loved landmarks and has been a meeting place for generations of both locals and visitors. It is the focal point of Weymouth's New Year's Eve celebrations as midnight approaches and revelers gather beneath its four faces to welcome in the New Year." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jubilee_clock#Weymouth still there: www.google.com/maps/@50.614081,-2.452862,3a,75y,12.36h,84...

comment_text: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tynemouth "Tynemouth is a town and a historic borough in Tyne & Wear, England, at the mouth of the River Tyne, between North Shields (on the Tyne) and Cullercoats (on the coast to the North)." In far northeast of England. Streetview www.google.com/maps/@55.022206,-1.421643,3a,75y,346.69h,9... The large building is gone. See www.mouthofthetyne.com/2014/04/01/tynemouth-plaza-a-short... for the story of the Plaza, destroyed in 1996 by a fire. The smaller building to its right does appear still to be there, from a StreetView run along the front -- housing some small shops.

comment_text: "Rusthall and the surrounding area features several sandstone outcrops. One of these formations, located in the Denny Bottom area, close to Rusthall Common, is known as Toad Rock because it resembles a sitting toad. The first known record of the rock's name is in an 1823 guide by J. Clifford, although the rock itself was first popularised in a local guide published in 1810. The fencing around the rock's base was first installed in 1881-2 and has since been renovated in 1993-94." The rock formation is not man-made, as was at first suspected, but was eroded into its current shape by wind action during the Ice Age. The area has been designated as a Site of Special Scientific Interest. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rusthall#Toad_Rock "Part of the Tunbridge Wells Sand Formation en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tunbridge_Wells_Sand_Formation recent street view: www.google.com/maps/@51.133875,0.240445,3a,75y,268.72h,78...

comment_text: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southport "Southport Pier is referred to as the first true "pleasure pier", being one of the earliest pier structures to be erected using iron. A design from James Brunlees was approved at a cost of £8,700 and on 4 August 1859 a large crowd witnessed the driving home of the first support pile. The opening of the pier was celebrated on 2 August 1860." "Southport Pier is a Grade II listed building in Southport, Merseyside, England. At 1,216 yards (1112 m) it is the second longest in Great Britain after Southend Pier." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southport_Pier Streetview: www.google.com/maps/@53.651207,-3.008372,3a,75y,272.43h,8...

Location: www.google.com/maps/place/Thulandang+Island,+Indonesien/@... The ship is obviously the "Van Overstraten". See also www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/15552786794/

comment_text: And the MCNY photo of the Postal Life Building, on the east side of 5th, shows Guaranty Trust's name in the stone facades along 43rd and 5th. So, I suppose what we see in this picture is the second location of the clock In front of Postal Life, then it was moved again to its present location near the southwest corner of 44th and 5th. Street view looking south, showing Postal Life Building on left, a block down. www.google.com/maps/@40.7548378,-73.9800553,3a,75y,233.82... If that's true, the Landmarks Commission document is inaccurate, unless Morgan Guaranty didn't move the clock back across the street until the 30's, which would seem odd.

comment_text: In Brooklyn, looking east from the Hudson River. The building with the dormers on the left is the Freight Office for the South Brooklyn Railway. That's now the location of the Sunset Park Costco. The loft warehouse in the center of the photo is still standing. It was one of the original "Bush Terminal" warehouses. The BT warehouse lofts are now known as "Industry City" and this is Building 19 of that complex. The Brooklyn Nets (NBA) are building their new $50 million training facility on the top floor of that building. Modern Google Street view

comment_text: From OCR of THE TIMES HISTORY OF THE WAR. Page 95 www.forgottenbooks.com/readbook_text/The_Times_History_of... "Between the villages of Biula and Gromnik, for a distance of about fourteen miles, the two armies [Russian and German/Austrian] were facing one another on the western lay almost entirely within the triangle, of which the Dunajec and the Biala are the sides, their confluence the apex, and of which the Zakliczvn-Gromnik road is the basis. About two miles to the south of the river junction, between Bogumilovice and Tarnow, the double tracked railway Cracow-Lwow crosses the Dunajec and the Biala. The big railway bridge across the Dunajec had been blown up by the Austrians during their second retreat in November 1914; the Russians replaced it by a wooden structure, but this in turn was destroyed by our Allies during their retreat from before Cracow about the middle of December. Since then the Dunajec had become at this point the unbridgable borderline between the armies, which slowly settled down to the routine of But as surprise attacks were in most parts impossible on account of the intervening river, sniping became the chief occupation of the troops in that sector. Behind the big eastern pillar of the broken bridge was the post of a Russian sniper, who by his exploits earned for himself among the enemy local fame and the nickname of " Ivan the Terrible "; he finished by becoming in turn the victim of a sniper." This looks to me as though it must be at www.google.com/maps/place/Bogumi%C5%82owice,+Poland/@50.0...

description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Pounds addressing Brooklyn team [between ca. 1915 and ca. 1920] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.22955 Call Number: LC-B2- 4010-4
comment_text: This is former Brooklyn Superbas pitcher Bill Pounds addressing the 1916 team as it left Brooklyn on October 6, 1916 to play the Boston Red Sox in the World Series. Presumably, that's him standing in the second street level window from the left, cupping his hands in front of his mouth. The Sun's account of the parade mentions the stop at the Y, but not Pounds. The sun. (New York [N.Y.]) , October 07, 1916, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-10-07/ed-... The Bedford Branch of the YMCA is still at the corner of Bedford and Monroe in Brooklyn, now the Bedford-Stuyvesant Branch. This building on the corner is now gone, but in the current Google Street View, the building across Monroe still stands, though now boarded up. www.google.com/maps/@40.685264,-73.954288,3a,75y,122.59h,... A copy of this photo that was auctioned had the following description: "This superb Bain image shows Bill Pounds addressing the Brooklyn Dodgers in front of the YMCA as they prepare to head to Boston for the 1916 World Series. A large crowd is gathered in front of the YMCA and cars are double parked in the street. A few police are on hand to maintain control but the crowd appears to be well behaved. Photo has along its top edge, in white “Pounds Addressing Bklyn Team.” To the right, in black, “4010-4.” Reverse has “Departure of Brooklyns from Brooklyn for Boston Oct. 6, 1916.” www.lelands.com/auction/AuctionDetail/28571/December-2005... "Jeared Wells "Bill" Pounds (March 11, 1878 – July 7, 1936) was a pitcher in Major League Baseball. He pitched in two games during the 1903 baseball season." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Pounds

NYT, 9/8/1916. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A01E7DC103DE3... A modern aerial view of the 240th Street Yard: www.nycsubway.org/perl/show?110804 Google Street View from Manhattan College Parkway: maps.google.com/maps?ll=40.857967,-73.859711&spn=0.39... See also

comment_text: The Hotel Woodstock was a luxury hotel on 43rd St., just off Times Square. In August, 1916 it served as the headquarters for the railroad union leaders, like Garretson, who came to Manhattan to participate in talks aimed at averting a national rail strike. The hotel is still in operation, though now mainly as housing for the indigent. www.projectfind.org/woodstock ephemeralnewyork.wordpress.com/tag/woodstock-hotel-43rd-s... An account of the atmosphere at the labor negotiations: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F40C15FC3E5D1A... The same spot, today: www.google.com/maps/@40.756173,-73.985184,3a,75y,51.29h,8...

comment_text: Labor celebration in Union Square, attended by 3,000 in the first organized labor participation in New York's municipal 4th of July festivities. Frank P. Walsh, he of the Industrial Relations (Walsh) Commission, of which there are many Bain photos, spoke, but I can't tell if that's him in this shot. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F70910FE355B17... This shot is taken looking southeast across the park from the north side, near 17th Street. Two buildings in the background, the second and third south of 16th Street and Union Square East, are still there, though some additional stories have been added. www.google.com/maps/@40.735781,-73.989663,3a,75y,113.61h,...

comment_text: This is the 7th Regiment leaving their armory from the Lexington Avenue side, between 66th and 67th Streets, for deployment on the Mexican Border on June 27, 1916. New York Sun, June 28, 1916 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1916-06-28/ed-... It looks about the same today, except for the cobblestone street, streetcar tracks and ornate lampposts: maps.google.com/maps?q=park+avenue+and+66th+street,+nyc&a... More on the regiment and the armory: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/7th_New_York_Militia en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seventh_Regiment_Armory www.nytimes.com/2012/10/14/realestate/seventh-regiment-ar...;

The soldiers that led each division of trades and occupations where the "Plattsburg enrolled men", which I assume is the New York National Guard. In this photo, the Silk Industry and Allied Interests Division, numbering 5,194 men. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50C11FD3F5D1773... This location today: maps.google.com/maps?q=everett+building,+nyc&ll=40.73... More on the history of the Everett Building:

comment_text: The Museum of the City of New York's online collection has 2 shots of the Eastern Hotel, located at the corner of Whitehall and South Streets in Manhattan. collections.mcny.org/C.aspx?VP3=SearchResult_VPage&VB... It was founded on that location in 1822. In 1912, the New York Times ran an account of its 90th birthday party. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10817F8345517738... The corner today is pretty drab by comparison: maps.google.com/maps?q=Whitehall+Street,+New+York,+NY&amp... See also:

comment_text: Apparently this was the third time this bridge over the Marne in northeastern France had been destroyed (this time by the British, in September, 1914, previously by the French in 1814 and 1870) to stop the advancing German army. books.google.com/books?id=MfSM14o6uqgC&lpg=PA57&o... The bridge in June, 2013, showing the repaired area: maps.google.com/maps?q=trilport+seine+et+marne+ile+de+fra... Another view from 1914: www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/the-ruins-of-the-br... Tinted version of postcard, showing caption redacted by Bain: images-01.delcampe-static.net/img_large/auction/000/244/6... Showing temporary reconstruction: images-01.delcampe-static.net/img_large/auction/000/241/5...
