comment_text: "The Royal Palace of Caserta (Italian: Reggia di Caserta, Italian pronunciation: [ˌrɛddʒa di kaˈzɛrta]) is a former royal residence in Caserta, southern Italy, constructed for the Bourbon kings of Naples. It was the largest palace and one of the largest buildings erected in Europe during the 18th century. In 1997, the Palace was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site, described in its nomination as "the swan song of the spectacular art of the Baroque, from which it adopted all the features needed to create the illusions of multidirectional space"." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palace_of_Caserta Street View: maps.google.com/maps?q=Royal+Palace+of+Caserta&ll=41....

description: [Kingsgate Castle, Margate, England] [between ca. 1890 and ca. 1900]. 1 photomechanical print : photochrom, color. comment_text: Apparently not in Margate, but in neighboring Broadstairs: "Kingsgate Castle on the cliffs above Kingsgate Bay, Broadstairs, Kent, was built for Lord Holland (Henry Fox, 1st Baron Holland) in the 1760s. The name Kingsgate is related to an incidental landing of Charles II on 30 June 1683 (‘gate’ referring to a cliff-gap) though other English monarchs have also used this cove, such as George II in 1748. The building was later the residence of John Lubbock, 1st Baron Avebury. The building has now been converted into 31 flats." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingsgate_Castle July, 2012 Street View: maps.google.com/maps?q=broadstairs+england,kingsgate+cast... More: "2. circa 1760 Lord Holland built a copy of a Welsh Edwardian castle to house his stables. This soon fell into ruin and the large round tower is all that remains of the original building. In the late C19 it was rebuilt by Lord Avebury. Quadrangular in shape. 2 to 3 storeys flint faced with stone long and short quoins and window dressings. Crenellated parapet. Windows are 3 light mullions." www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-417608-kingsgate-cast...

comment_text: This was almost certainly taken outside the War Office in London on the occasion of Joffre's previously unpublicized visit with Kitchener on October 29, 1915. According to this account, they left the building at 1:30 p.m. that day together. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30615F6355A1573... Old War Office building entrance, street view: maps.google.com/maps?q=map+whitehall,+london&ll=51.50...

Dating originally from 1765, it was once home to three very pretty young ladies whose story was later celebrated in a poem. They were so choosey about their perspective husbands that they ended up unmarried and known as the Three Old Maids of Lee." (from www.oldmaidscottage.co.uk/) Nothing Swiss in this IMO.

comment_text: Also from Google Streetview !!!! - maps.google.com/maps?q=53.276,-1.656&ll=53.276711,-1.... "Lovers Leap - In 1762 Hannah Baddaley was the most beautiful girl in Stoney Middleton. Unable to face the future after being rejected by her lover, William Barnsley, she climbed the cliff above you, proclaimed her love for William and jumped. Her woollen petticoats billowed out and parachuted her down to safety. Cured of her desire for William, she died December 12th 1764."

comment_text: This is taken from the sidewalk on the east side of 7th Avenue, looking north toward 24th Street. Both corner buildings are still there: goo.gl/maps/jwZB3 The new subway tunnel was still under construction and the street surface was a temporary wooden tunnel roof. A trolley car full of passengers was passing over when the roof collapsed into the tunnel. See details under

It's not visible from the street anymore, because the street is in a forest now (Street View). The stones at the edge of the street are still there. Another photo from 1908: www.francisfrith.com/gunnislake/photos/weir-head-1908_59707/

comment_text: "Port Gaverne (Cornish: Porthkaveran) is a hamlet on the north coast of Cornwall, England, about half a mile east of Port Isaac. Although recognised as an independent hamlet by the Cornish, many tourists consider it as part of the larger village of Port Isaac, partially due to the reason it is home to only four businesses: two hotels, a campsite and a small seasonal beach shop." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_Gaverne Street View

NYT of August 20, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0F17F63E5D16738... reports on the return of his body and identifies the house as 152 Underhill Avenue, Brooklyn. comment_text: This is taken from the west side of 9th Avenue at 13th st. looking southeast toward Little West 12th St. . The white building across the tracks is still there: maps.google.com/maps?q=9th+avenue,+13th+street+and+hudson... In 1915, the line updated its express stops to a "hump express" configuration, where the center express track was elevated at the express stations. Wing and Son was a piano manufacturer located at between Hudson, 9th Ave and 13th St. The 9th Ave. El was demolished in 1940.

description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Judge Franklin C. Hoyt [between ca. 1910 and ca. 1915] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. comment_text: Judge Hoyt was a pioneer in what is now called juvenile justice. This photo was probably used in connection with stories on the opening of the new Children's Court building, at 137 E. 22d St. in August, 1915. (the building still stands as part of Baruch College). Also, a law for the first time separating New York criminal courts from the Children's Court had gone into effect on July 1, 1915. "WHAT NEW CHILDREN'S COURT IS; Justice Hoyt Talks of What Has Been Called "the Greatest Life Saving Station in the World" query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50912F83C5D17738... Hoyt was also president of the Big Brothers movement from 1911-1925, and of the Boy Scouts in the Bronx and Manhattan. After his retirement from the bench he became Federal alcohol administrator in 1935. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/Ne... Children's Courthouse history: www.preserve2.org/gramercy/proposes/ext/ension/137e22.htm June, 2011 Google Street View: maps.google.com/maps?q=lexington+avenue+and+22d+street,+n... Marriage license info: Dutchess County Date of License- June 1, 1918 Date of Marriage- June 8, 1918 Place of Marriage- Wappingers Falls Official- Prescott Evarts, clergyman Witnesses: John Borland, W. Willis Reese Groom Name/Age/Race/: Franklin Chase Hoyt, blank, blank, blank Resides – Westchester N Y City, Justice-Lawyer, b. Pelham, NY Father- William Sprague Hoyt b. US Mother- Janet R. Chase b. US Bride Name/Age/Race: Maud Rives Borland, 32, White 1st marriage Resides- Wappingers Falls, occ-none, b. New York Father- John Borland b. US Mother- Constance Rives b. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print Part Of: Views of Great Britain and Ireland, primarily England (DLC) 2002696059 More information about the Photochrom Print Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.pgz Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ppmsc.08006 Call Number: LOT 13415, no. 028 [item]
comment_text: And that is John Webster's suspension footbridge (1888) in the background, still a major local landmark. Here's the Google Street View from the roadway in back of where this photo was taken: maps.google.com/maps?q=32+the+embankment,+bedford,+englan... The area is no longer referred to as the the recreation grounds, but as The Embankment. I think the two kids here are the same ones in the Howard Statue Photochrom that precedes this. Their clothes are the same, but of different colors in the 2 pictures, but the Photochrom process, as I understand it, starts with a black and white photo which is then separated by color on multiple lithograph plates, each with a different color ink, which are then each printed on the composite final print. So the color choice is made by the printer, and isn't necessarily the color of the original scene.

title: Bliss Torpedo Works  (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Bliss Torpedo Works [between ca. 1910 and ca. 1915] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards. Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.19621 Call Number: LC-B2- 3555-6
comment_text: This building still stands, at 135 Plymouth Street in Brooklyn. That is the Manhattan Bridge at top (and the shadow on the corner of the building). This picture was probably taken in connection with the labor unrest at the plant in late July, 1915. The plant was making Whitehead torpedoes for the Navy. Biiss asked the City for permission to post armed guards on the Manhattan Bridge above the plant to prevent bombs being thrown down onto the building. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70612FB3C5D1773... The building across Plymouth, at the lower right is also extant, though with bricked-up windows and the parapet removed. Here is a view of the same scene in June, 2011: maps.google.com/maps?q=135+plymouth+street+brooklyn+ny&am... Some information on E.W. Bliss (Eliphalet Williams Bliss) and this factory at: boards.ancestry.com/topics.researchresources.genealogists... Another Bain shot of a Bliss building: Poster for Rubsam and Horrmann beer (see note on photo):

title: Morse aeroplane capsized  (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Morse aeroplane capsized [between ca. 1910 and ca. 1915] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards. Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.19546 Call Number: LC-B2- 3547-8
comment_text: I'm certain the location of this shot is the Hudson River, at about 131st Street. Conron Bros. Poultry Co. had a Manhattanville cold storage plant at 131st and 12th Avenue. The tall building at left is probably part of that. books.google.com/books?id=Tp9OAAAAYAAJ&dq=conron%20br... In the background, with the spectators on the roadway watching the recovery, is the Riverside Drive Viaduct, running above 12th Avenue in West Harlem between 120th St. (St. Clair Place) and 134th Street, and built in 1900. To the far right of what can be seen of the viaduct is the wider steel sheathing under the roadway that marks the 125th Street arch, the especially wide arch needed to span that intersection at 12th Avenue. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riverside_Drive_Viaduct September 2011 Google Street View from the Henry Hudson Parkway maps.google.com/maps?q=brook+avenue,+nyc+map&hl=en&am... This site is now West Harlem Piers Park. Here is an undated photo showing the now-demolished piers along this stretch of the Hudson, along with river ferries. The Conron Bros. building is in the center of the photo in front of the huge storage tank. c1038.r38.cf3.rackcdn.com/group1/building3963/media/fig7a...

title: Thaw Leaving Court -- Jul 1915  (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Thaw Leaving Court -- Jul 1915 1915 July (date created or published later by Bain) 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title and date from data provided by the Bain News Service on the negative. Photograph shows Harry Kendall Thaw (1871-1947) leaving court during the jury trial on the issue of his sanity. (Source: Flickr Commons project, 2012) Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.19513 Call Number: LC-B2- 3544-3
comment_text: In July, 1915, Thaw had a jury trial solely on the issue of his present sanity, bearing on whether he would be returned to the Matteawan State Hospital from which he had escaped 2 years earlier. The trial was in the Tweed Courthouse, still standing on Chambers Street. This picture is more likely to be Thaw heading to court, rather than leaving, as it looks like he is on Centre and Chambers, walking toward the courthouse. That would put it in front of the Manhattan Municipal Building, which has an arched pathway through its center. www.nyc.gov/html/dcas/html/resources/man_munibldg.shtml The spot in July, 2011 via Google Street View: maps.google.com/maps?q=51+chambers+street,+nyc&ll=40.... See notes under: Reflecting further, I suppose he could be on the presumably identical inside of the passageway, therefore heading away from court.

title: Garment Workers' Strike, July 1915  (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Garment Workers' Strike, July 1915 1915 July (date created or published later by Bain) 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from data provided by the Bain News Service on the negative. Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.19510 Call Number: LC-B2- 3543-15
comment_text: This is taken from an upper story window near 62 Essex Street, at the corner of Essex Market Place, a street which was closed in 1926 which ran between Essex and Ludlow, on the block between Grand and Broome. Coincidentally, the photo 2 in front of this one in the news stream was taken at the other end of Essex Market Place, at the Ludlow corner, in front of the Ludlow Street Jail. The buildings on both sides of this block have been demolished since this photo was taken. The building on the northeast corner of Essex and Broome, just visible in back of the wagon at the very top under the word July, is still there. The details of the spirited conversations, pushcart vendors and street life on the Lower East Side in general are well captured. It's not unlikely that the same photographer took both photos on the same day. This picture is wonderful in the highest resolution at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.19510 . The view from the approximate location, at street level, in July, 2011: maps.google.com/maps?q=62+essex+street,+nyc&ll=40.716...

comment_text: A picture of the Beckers at the time of his second murder trial in 1914: news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19140512&... The building at 2291 University Avenue in the Bronx, where Helen Becker lived, was also where her husband's body was brought following her husband's execution at Sing Sing on July 30, 1915. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9407EFDF1138E633A... The building and its neighbors look more or less the same in this 2011 Google Street View image, though the gas street lamp has been replaced by an electric one, the stained glass on the stairway windows has been replaced, the basement windows bricked in, and fire escapes added: maps.google.com/maps?q=2291+university+avenue,+n.y.&l...

Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.19303 Call Number: LC-B2- 3515-1
comment_text: better link: www.nycgovparks.org/parks/greeleysquarepark/highlights/13313 Interestingly enough, the NY Parks site is misleading. There are two similar Greeley statues. For some reason they accurately describe the one pictured above as in City Hall Park, but they picture it on the Greeley Park page of their site. On the City Hall Park page, they accurately describe the statue there (pictured above in the Bain photo) but they mistakenly picture the Greeley Square statue. www.nycgovparks.org/parks/cityhallpark/highlights/13314 The most obvious difference is that Greeley has a newspaper spread out on his right thigh in the City Hall Park statue, and has a book hanging down in his right hand in the Greeley Square one. maps.google.com/maps?q=greeley+square,+new+york&ll=40...

title: [unidentified entrance to bldg. -- Rasch Studio]  (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. [unidentified entrance to bldg. -- Rasch Studio] [between ca. 1910 and ca. 1915] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from data provided by the Bain News Service on the caption card. cards. Photograph shows the entrance to the Chatworth Apartments, 344 West 72nd Street, New York City which was the location of the dance studio of choreographer and dancer Albertina Rasch (1891-1967). (Source: Flickr Commons project, 2012) Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.19188 Call Number: LC-B2- 3490-8
comment_text: ok, I think I've found it, in the New York Times on October 21, 1923: *** ALBERTINA RASCH Now preparing her Company for her CONCERT TOUR has opened her DANCE STUDIO 344 W. 72d St., New York City. Tel. Endicott 7589 CLASS — PRIVATE LESSON —BALLET INTERPRETIVE—DANCES ARRANGED. New York recitals in the early Spring. We can place pupils when qualifying *** So, the building is still there, the Chatsworth Apartments, built in 1904. It looks like W. 72d St. used to end on a bluff over the Hudson, but it was redesigned into onramps and offramps from Riverside Blvd. and the Henry Hudson parkway. Still pretty nice location, but not the dreamy little corner it once was. If you look up to the very top on Google Street View, there are slanted windows that match the ones in the pictures of the studio rooms. maps.google.com/maps?q=344+w.+72d+street,+ny&ll=40.78... If you have a spare $150 Million, it might still be for sale: online.wsj.com/article/SB10000872396390444318104577587540... And here is an analysis of The Chatsworth, done in connection with its landmark designation: www.landmarkwest.org/maps_and_data/Designation%20Reports/...

comment_text: Though officially allied with Germany and Austria-Hungary, Italy entered the war on May 23, 1915 on the side of England, France and Russia. This led to huge, peaceful demonstrations in New York's Italian neighborhoods. The Italian Consulate was at that time at 226 Lafayette St, on Cleveland Place in Little Italy. According to a New York Times account, it was one of the busiest places in New York that week, owing to the fact that it kept track of the 200,000 Italian army and navy reservists in New York. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30617FA385C1373... select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10B1EF83A5A1773... Both buildings in the picture are still there: maps.google.com/maps?q=226+lafayette+st+nyc&ll=40.722...

comment_text: The park was dedicated on April 15, 1915, the third anniversary of the death of Isidore and Ida Straus in the sinking of the Titanic. Mr. Straus was a department store magnate, co-owner of both Macy's and Abraham & Straus department stores. The park is still there, but a 90's renovation subsituted a planted area in lieu of the original pool: maps.google.com/maps?q=straus+park+,+new+york&ll=40.8...

comment_text: Here's a New York Times Account of the Bundle Day drive by the Mayor's Committee on Unemployment, which included notables like Mrs. Vincent Astor, Mrs. Peter Cooper Hewitt and Mrs. Conrnelius Vanderbilt. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30912FE355B1373... This was shot at Bundle Day Headquarters at 210 Fifth Avenue, the Mark Cross Building. Here's another contemporary account: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-02-05/ed-... The building is still there: maps.google.com/maps?q=210+fifth+avenue,+new+york+ny&...

comment_text: S. also article in The Ogden standard., August 31, 1914, 4 P.M. City Edition, Page 10, col. 6: "A German aviator flew over Paris this afternoon and dropped five bombs which fell in the most populous quarter of the city. In one case two women were wounded. ... Two others dropped in the Rue des Recollets and Rue Marcin, neither of which exploded. The aviator, who signed himself Lieutenant von Heldssen, dropped manifestos, in which were written: "The German army is at the gates of Paris, you can do nothing but surrender." " chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058396/1914-08-31/ed-... Street view: www.google.com/maps/@48.8743444,2.3623617,3a,90y,230.91h,...

comment_text: This is the Brasserie Bougeneaux in the Boulevard de Strasbourg, 10th Arrondissement of Paris: Baedeker: Paris and Environs, 1913: Gare de l'Est (PI. B, 24; p. 217) : Brass. Bougeneaux, 9 Rue de Strasbourg, corner of the boulevard ; No. 11, Rest. Schaeffer, good ; No. 13, Rest. de l'Hot. Français (Barbotte); No. 8, Coeurdoux plain, but good; No. 6, corner of Rue d'Alsace, Bouillon Duval; No. 5, Terminus Est, at the hotel (p. 10). — Drouant, 79 Boul. de Strasbourg, corner of Rue St-Laurent, a large and very popular establishment (oysters). Today's view: maps.google.com/maps?q=9,+bd+de+strasbourg,+paris The Bd de Strasbourg does in fact lead directly to the Gare de l'Est (note correct capitalization). [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5939636361/]

comment_text: This is the Kierbedzia Bridge (built 1859 - 1864). After its destruction during World War II the bridge was rebuilt in 1949 – without its trademark latticework – as the Śląsko-Dąbrowski Bridge (www.warsawtour.pl/en/about-warsaw/old-warsaw-on-photograp...) See also de.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%9Al%C4%85sko-D%C4%85browski-Br%... (German) View in 2011: Street View There is no "Alexandrowk Bridge" in Warsaw, as far I can see. The bridge was designed by Stanisław Kierbedź, a Polish engineer who constructed the Blagoveshchensky / Nikolaevsky Bridge in St. Petersburg as well (photo nearby)

Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.15215 Call Number: LC-B2- 2960-16
comment_text: 293 Bowery @ Houston, looking north along the short block to E. 1st Street. There's some kind of garden and a glassed-in apartment building called the Avalon there now (Google Street View). A little more about the buildings on the right: "Between 1884 and 1932, the Bowery YMCA, housed for a time at Wesley Hall (291-293 Bowery), also provided mission-style services and housing. Today the building houses a Tibetan Buddhist meditation and teaching center. McGurk’s Suicide Hall at 295 Bowery also became a rescue mission for a time during the early 20th century." www.placeinhistory.org/projects/bowery/?page=10 50 years earlier (1863), the same spot was the location of a huge hotel fire covered in the NY Times. The building next door (295 Bowery) was a tobacco warehouse heavily damaged by water during the fighting of the fire.

description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Cleveland storm damage, 11/13 11/13 (date created or published later by Bain) 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards. Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.14800 Call Number: LC-B2- 2903-9
comment_text: This image, of the Hotel Collinwood, was taken in what was at the time Collinwood village, and what has since been annexed to the city of Cleveland. The hotel was located on the west side of Collamer Avenue (now East 152nd Street), the fourth building north of Collins Avenue (now Saranac Road). The approximate location can be seen in Google Maps. How do I know this? In the plate glass window in the center of the picture, I've noted the name "Collinwood Hotel Restaurant". It can be seen in the center of the inset in this detail of the 1903 Sanborn fire insurance map for the area: The shape of the building in the photo corresponds exactly to the shape of the Hotel Collinwood building on the Sanborn map. The street numbers do not correspond due to a change in the numbering system for the streets that occurred in 1905. Further evidence of the location is provided by this plate from the 1921 Plat Book of the City of Cleveland. It shows the correct profile for the building, and gives the address as 630 - the number shown on the building in the photo. A streetcar is visible, slightly out of focus, at the right edge of the photograph. This corresponds to the streetcar tracks shown on the map in the Plat Book.

comment_text: If it is not Nice, it may be Frejus seen from St-Raphael ; there is an old bridge there like the one pictured. Both latter cities are also on the French Riviera. maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geo... Beaches in Nice are not made out of sand but of "galets" (small roundish stones), somehow I would then say it is Nice but the only 2 bridges on the seashore do not seem to match. Last hint: in France, only 2 categories of buildings wear high the French flag: official buildings and most hotels. I first thought of the Negresco hotel (in Nice) but it has a dome on its front side. But the hotel was built in 1912... What still makes me doubt it is Nice (or Frejus) is the stone construction; why would they had to remove it?

comment_text: A view of the Old Port ("Vieux-Port") of Marseille in France. It is similar to this one, though apparently taken from the Quai du Port. The Église Notre-Dame-des-Accoules, visible in this alternate view of the port, peeks out above the buildings on the right. A roughly equivalent modern-day view can be seen using Google Maps' street view.

title: MAINE Monument  (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. MAINE Monument 1913 May 27 (date created or published later by Bain) 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title and date from data provided by the Bain News Service on the negative. Corresponding print in LOT 10949 is cropped version of negative. Photo shows memorial to the battleship Maine, which had exploded in the harbor of Havana, Cuba, during the Spanish-American War of 1898. In 1913, the monument was placed at the Columbus Circle and 59th Street entrance to Central Park in New York City. (Source: New York Times, Central Park Web site, and Flickr Commons project, 2009) Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.13075 Call Number: LC-B2- 2698-9
comment_text: Streetview www.centralparknyc.org/visit/things-to-see/south-end/main...

comment_text: "John Barrett (November 28, 1866 – October 17, 1938) was a United States diplomat and one of the most influential early directors general of the Pan American Union." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Barrett_%28diplomat%29 The photo was taken in front of the Pan American Union building in Washington (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pan_American_Union_Building, Streetview: maps.google.com/maps?q=17th+Street+NW&ll=38.892893,-7...) The photo is perhaps taken at the same occasion as this (and others, see comments):

comment_text: Actually it's now "Frederiksborg Slot, Hillerød, Denmark", but when the picture was taken, the spelling in this picture could very well have been correct. I live just 1500 meters from here, and my grandfather used to work as a gardener in the park around the castle. He lived in a little house just outside the frame of this picture. Frederiksborg Castle isn't situated in Copenhagen, but in Hillerød, approximately 35 km from the center of Copenhagen. It is now a museum where you can see a large collection of historic paintings.

title: Essex troop  (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Essex troop [between ca. 1910 and ca. 1915] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards. Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.12491 Call Number: LC-B2- 2632-9
comment_text: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jon_loc] You may be right. The date on the sticker is 2/6/13, at that time the newspapers reported that the Essex troop would be President Wilson's personal escort (see e.g. The Washington times., February 06, 1913, LAST EDITION, Page 4, col. 2), the parade depicted on the photo could be much earlier. According to njbottles.com/index.php?topic=5375.0, Scheuer's location in Newark was 736 Broad Street, thats where now the National Newark Building, erected in 1931, is standing (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Newark_Building). The photo is probably made from this angle: www.google.com/maps?ll=40.736169,-74.171866&spn=0.007.... The park in the background then is the Military Park. None of the buildings of 1913 visible on the photo has survived.

Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.12480 Call Number: LC-B2- 2631-7
comment_text: This is the corner of Lafayette Street and White Street in New York City. I can tell because building on the far right is the Engine Company 31 Firehouse (Napoleon Le Brun & Sons, 1895). I have a current photo of it; it looks nearly the same except for some roofing detail, but a photo of the same corner from 1907 (scroll all the way down) shows the detailing intact. Another bit of evidence: the street address for the firehouse is 87-91 Lafayette Street, while the signage on the corner building shows the number "84" (backwards), which is presumably part of its street address. Additionally, according to Google Maps, the tall building in the middle with the arched windows at the top is still standing--it's at Lafayette and Walker, a block away. I'm going to guess that Hartigan was rushing over to the New York State Supreme Court building (as per Mr. Angstrom above) a few blocks down south.

comment_text: Anyone who has been to New York City should recognize the building. It is 225 Madison Avenue at 36th Street. It is the Morgan Library. The empty lot to the right now contains the modern addition to the museum. In the fictional account in Ragtime it is the place where Coalhouse Walker has his siege until his soiled car is cleaned and returned to him. Here it is in Google streetview: maps.google.com/maps?q=225+Madison+Avenue+at+36th+Street,... Here it is in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierpont_Morgan_Library

comment_text: There's a Las Vegas in New Mexico too. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Las_Vegas,_New_Mexico Including Johnson, he and the men to the right are numbered 1, 5, 2, 3, 4. And the man 2nd to the right of the column behind them is numbered with a reversed "6" Here is the key: 1. Jack Johnson 2. W. Burns 3. C. Respress 4. Perkins 5 J. Cannon reversed 6. C. O'Malley Johnson had his training camp in Las Vegas, New Mexico to prepare for his july 4, 1912 bout with Jim Flynn. So this photograph was taken shortly before that date, and probably in front of what is today the address 2008 North Gonzales Street. ref.: lasvegasnmcchp.com/tours/oldtown/4johnson.htm maps.google.com.au/maps?f=q&hl=en&geocode=&q=...

comment_text: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Gould Helen Gould was the daughter of railroad "robber baron" Jay Gould. He died in 1892 and his house passed down to his daughter(s) (sister Anna donated it to the Natl Trust). The Gould home had a name, Lyndhurst. Here is an article about Lyndhurst, including its association with Dark Shadows: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyndhurst_(house) Here is the Lyndurst website: www.lyndhurst.org/ Here is its location on Google Maps: maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&geocode=&q=lyn...

title: Fire rescue work  (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Fire rescue work [1912 Oct. 9] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from data provided by the Bain News Service on the negative. Photo shows a fire drill exercise at the National Cloak and Suit Company, Seventh Avenue, New York City, on Oct. 9, 1912. (Source: Flickr Commons project, 2008, and New York Times) Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.11181 Call Number: LC-B2- 2481-8
comment_text: Same location as this photo, the National Cloak & Suit Company building. According to the NYT, the National Cloak and Suit Company occupied "the entire west side of the block on Seventh Avenue between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Street" in New York City. A look at Google Maps' Street View confirms that it's this location, 250 Seventh Avenue, currently a Whole Foods store. There is also an October 10, 1912 story about city-wide fire drill exercises the previous day, one of which took place at the building, so this picture could have been taken on October 9, 1912, unless there other fire drills of this type taken in other years.

comment_text: Awesome!! Thanks for the info, MGA66! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/MGA66/] This picture matches the pictures of the building on Oficina Estatal de Conservación Histórica. The register says the building's address is Calle San José #54 Viejo San Juan. Since the picture shows the San Juan Bay in the background, I'll estimate that the picture was taken from another tall building in the same block, but located on Calle Cruz. I updated the Geotags for this picture to point to the location of the subject (El Mundo newspaper building).

comment_text: I really like the detail of the woman hanging clothes to dry on the roof top! Gelocation tags are for the listed address for the tall building in the picture, El Mundo Newspaper, from Oficina Estatal de Conservación Histórica. The register says the building's address is Calle San José #54 Viejo San Juan. Since the picture shows the San Juan Bay in the background, I infer the picture was taken from another tall building in the same block, but located on Calle Cruz.

description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Morner House near Albany [1911 Dec.] 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title from data provided by the Bain News Service on the negative. comment_text: Other articles pin the farm as being close to Troy, NY. There is a Morner Road in Rensselaer. This house looks exactly like the one just east of Best Road on Morner Road, check out Google Maps. The barn in the back also generally matches the LOC photo of the Morner barn. Interesting that the page 1 story ran right next to McNamara... and LOC also has photos of a barn for that trial.

comment_text: OK, got it! A few more minutes in Google Streetview paid off. The viewpoint is at 8 Constitution Ave. NE facing eastbound. title: Labor union parade, NY., May 1, 1911  (LOC)
description: Bain News Service,, publisher. Labor union parade, NY., May 1, 1911 1911 May 1 (date created or published later by Bain) 1 negative : glass ; 5 x 7 in. or smaller. Notes: Title and date from data provided by the Bain News Service on the negative. Photograph shows the annual trade union May Day parade passing the corner of 13th and University Place, New York City. The parade paid special tribute to the victims of the recent Triangle Shirtwaist Company Fire (March 11, 1911). One sign in Yiddish notes "146" the number of fire victims. (Source: Flickr Commons project, 2008 and New York Times, May 2, 1911) Forms part of: George Grantham Bain Collection (Library of Congress). Subjects: NY Format: Glass negatives. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print General information about the Bain Collection is available at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ggbain Higher resolution image is available (Persistent URL): hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.09166 Call Number: LC-B2- 2193-1
comment_text: Fur business in the foreground is addressed 121. Based on link epicharmus supplied, it's 121 University Place. That's currently a business called Bar 13. Here's the scene in Google maps streetview. Note that the Ninth Regiment plaque, installed in 1908, used to be to the left of the entrance. Now it's to the right, on the corner (as described in ephicharmus' link, and visible in streetview).
